title: Czechoslovak New Wave
text:
The Czechoslovak New Wave (also Czech New Wave) is a term used for the Czechoslovak filmmakers who started making movies in the 1960s. The directors commonly included are <a href="Milo%C5%A1%20Forman">Miloš Forman</a>, <a href="V%C4%9Bra%20Chytilov%C3%A1">Věra Chytilová</a>, <a href="Ivan%20Passer">Ivan Passer</a>, <a href="Pavel%20Jur%C3%A1%C4%8Dek">Pavel Juráček</a>, <a href="Ji%C5%99%C3%AD%20Menzel">Jiří Menzel</a>, <a href="Jan%20N%C4%9Bmec">Jan Němec</a>, <a href="Jaromil%20Jire%C5%A1">Jaromil Jireš</a>, <a href="Vojt%C4%9Bch%20Jasn%C3%BD">Vojtěch Jasný</a>, <a href="Evald%20Schorm">Evald Schorm</a>, <a href="Hynek%20Bo%C4%8Dan">Hynek Bočan</a>, <a href="Juraj%20Herz">Juraj Herz</a>, <a href="Juraj%20Jakubisko">Juraj Jakubisko</a>, <a href="%C5%A0tefan%20Uher">Štefan Uher</a> and others. The movement was sometimes called the "Czechoslovak film miracle".
Overview.
The films touched on themes which for earlier film makers in the <a href="communism">communist</a> countries had rarely managed to avoid the objections of the censor, such as the misguided youths of Czechoslovak society portrayed in <a href="Milo%C5%A1%20Forman">Miloš Forman</a>'s "<a href="Black%20Peter%20%28film%29">Black Peter</a>" (1963) and "<a href="Loves%20of%20a%20Blonde">Loves of a Blonde</a>" (1965), or those caught in a surrealistic whirlwind in <a href="V%C4%9Bra%20Chytilov%C3%A1">Věra Chytilová</a>'s "<a href="Daisies%20%28film%29">Daisies</a>" (1966) and <a href="Jaromil%20Jire%C5%A1">Jaromil Jireš</a>' "<a href="Valerie%20a%20t%C3%BDden%20div%C5%AF">Valerie and Her Week of Wonders</a>" (1970). The films often expressed dark and absurd humour in opposition to social realist films of the 1950s.
The Czechoslovak New Wave differed from the <a href="French%20New%20Wave">French New Wave</a> in that it usually held stronger narratives, and as these directors were the children of a nationalized film industry, they had greater access to studios and state funding. They also made more adaptations, including <a href="Jaromil%20Jire%C5%A1">Jaromil Jireš</a>'s <a href="The%20Joke%20%28film%29">adaptation</a> of <a href="Milan%20Kundera">Milan Kundera</a>'s novel "<a href="The%20Joke%20%28novel%29">The Joke</a>" (1969). At the Fourth Congress of the Czechoslovak Writers Union in 1967, <a href="Milan%20Kundera">Milan Kundera</a> described this wave of national cinema as an important part of the history of Czechoslovak literature. Forman's "<a href="The%20Firemen%27s%20Ball">The Firemen's Ball</a>" (1967), another major film of the era, remains a <a href="cult%20film">cult film</a> more than four decades after its release.
Czech film.
The majority of films shot during the New Wave were Czech-language as opposed to <a href="Slovak%20language">Slovak</a>. Many directors came from the prestigious <a href="Film%20and%20TV%20School%20of%20The%20Academy%20of%20Performing%20Arts%20in%20Prague">FAMU</a>, located in Prague, while the state-run <a href="Barrandov%20Studios">Barrandov Studios</a> were located just on the outskirts of Prague. Some prominent Czech directors included <a href="Milo%C5%A1%20Forman">Miloš Forman</a>, who directed "<a href="The%20Firemen%27s%20Ball">The Firemen's Ball</a>", "<a href="Black%20Peter%20%28film%29">Black Peter</a>", and "<a href="Loves%20of%20a%20Blonde">Loves of a Blonde</a>" during this time, <a href="V%C4%9Bra%20Chytilov%C3%A1">Věra Chytilová</a> who is best known for her film "<a href="Daisies%20%28film%29">Daisies</a>", and <a href="Ji%C5%99%C3%AD%20Menzel">Jiří Menzel</a>, whose film "<a href="Closely%20Watched%20Trains">Closely Watched Trains</a>" ("Ostře sledované vlaky" 1966) won an <a href="Academy%20Award">Academy Award</a> for Best Foreign Language Film.
Slovak film.
"<a href="The%20Shop%20on%20Main%20Street">The Shop on Main Street</a>" (1965) won the <a href="Academy%20Award">Academy Award</a> for Best Foreign Language Film in 1966. Although it is not considered part of the New Wave, because it was directed by <a href="J%C3%A1n%20Kad%C3%A1r">Ján Kadár</a> and <a href="Elmar%20Klos">Elmar Klos</a>, who were a generation older, and the film is fairly traditional. <a href="Juraj%20Jakubisko">Juraj Jakubisko</a>, <a href="%C5%A0tefan%20Uher">Štefan Uher</a> or <a href="Du%C5%A1an%20Han%C3%A1k">Dušan Hanák</a> were Slovak filmmakers who were part of the New Wave.
